Project Number: 52197-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2018 
 
 
 
 
Mongolia: Strengthening the Anticorruption Regime 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
Policy.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The Government of Mongolia requested knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) 
from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help it strengthen the anticorruption regime. The TA 
team will complete a thorough diagnostic assessment of the case flow of corruption cases. Based 
on the assessment, it will then provide training and make recommendations for  legislative 
changes that would rectify the areas identified for improvement. The TA is consistent with the 
objectives of ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2017–2020, for Mongolia.1 The TA is closely 
aligned  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2030,2 in  particular  the  operational  priority  of  strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity to ensure less corruption and more equitable growth.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Corruption is considered by many to be widespread in Mongolia. In the most recent 
corruption perception index prepared by Transparency International, Mongolia ranked 103rd out 
of 180 countries surveyed.4 Mongolia’s ranking had worsened significantly from 2016, when it 
was ranked 87th. This arises from the slow process of resolving corruption cases at trials, 
dismissals without penalty, and uncompensated state losses. A survey conducted by the Asia 
Foundation shows consistency of opinion that corruption is the most important problem facing 
Mongolia (after unemployment), and 75.8% of respondents believe that corruption is a common 
practice in Mongolia.5 Transparency International made recommendations to Mongolia to improve 
its ranking by pointing out the need to (i) create a conducive legal environment to fight corruption; 
(ii) ensure that judges and prosecutors make fair decisions; (iii) strengthen the independence of 
the investigation, prosecution, and adjudication processes; and (iv) make procurement and 
budget expenditures accountable and transparent. 
 
3.  The government has placed high priority on reducing corruption in its efforts to promote 
sustainable development. The Sustainable Development Vision 2030 identifies the need to build 
a culture of professional, stable, and participative governance, free of corruption and conducive 
to implementing development policies at all levels.6 One of the principles of governance under the 
Sustainable Development Vision is to enforce ethics in the public sector and eliminate corruption. 
In addition, the Parliament of Mongolia passed a resolution for the introduction of the National 
Anticorruption Strategy in 2016.7 The strategy sets clear directions that the government should 
embrace to fight corruption: (i) improve the knowledge and skills of law enforcement agencies to 
effectively detect, investigate, prosecute, and adjudicate crimes related to corruption and misuse 
of office power; and (ii) build a system whereby resolutions of cases of corruption and misuse of 
power are analyzed. More recently, in the Three Pillar Development Policy,8 the government 
outlines the strengthening of fair, disciplined, responsible, and stable government systems as a 
core pillar. 
 
4.  The Independent Agency Against Corruption (IAAC) is the institution responsible for 
leading and overseeing the National Anticorruption Strategy and, along with the National Police, 
                                                
1  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2017–2020—Sustaining Inclusive Growth in a Period of 
Economic Difficulty. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 30 October 2018. 
4  Transparency International. 2017. Corruption Perceptions Index 2017. Berlin. 
5  The Asia Foundation. 2018. Survey on Perceptions and Knowledge of Corruption. Ulaanbaatar. 
6  The State Great Khural of Mongolia. 2016. Mongolia Sustainable Development Vision 2030. Ulaanbaatar. 
7  The State Great Khural of Mongolia. 2016. The National Anti-Corruption Strategy. Ulaanbaatar. 
8  Government of Mongolia. 2018. The Three-Pillar Development Policy. Ulaanbaatar.

2 
is responsible for receiving and investigating anticorruption cases. The General Prosecutor Office 
(GPO) is responsible for prosecution, the Judicial General Council (JGC) is responsible for 
overseeing the adjudication, and the Ministry of Justice and Home Affairs is responsible for overall 
policy and overseeing the administration of justice. 
 
5.  Despite the commitment of the government to fight corruption, as reflected in its policy 
documents, further efforts are required for success. The Anticorruption Law has not been updated 
significantly since 2006, yet the key agencies concerned with the fight against corruption are 
handling corruption cases that have become more sophisticated and increasingly involve financial 
crime. These agencies are also seeking to draw on digital technology, both as part of their 
enforcement techniques and to strengthen their communication with the public. This suggests 
that changes are required to ensure that the law is fit for the purpose and that investigators, 
prosecutors, and judges have the skills and means to fight corruption effectively. 
 
6.  Against this background, ADB will work with IAAC, GPO, and JGC to conduct an in-depth 
assessment of the corruption case flow process and define the areas in need of reform. ADB will 
then support IAAC, GPO, and JGC in reforming these areas with updated and more effective 
legislation, guidelines, and recommendations; and provide targeted training to strengthen the 
capacity of investigators, prosecutors, and judges. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: risk of corruption at all levels of government 
and society reduced (footnote 6). The TA will have the following outcome: anticorruption regime 
in Mongolia strengthened.9 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Diagnostic assessment of the reporting, investigation, prosecution, and 
adjudication of corruption cases prepared. The output will start with a self-assessment by 
IAAC, GPO, and JGC and involve the examination of the implementation and effectiveness of the 
legal and regulatory framework as well as the adequacy of the resources, and the capacity and 
independence of the law enforcement agencies dealing with corruption cases. The assessment 
will also consider international best practice for jurisdictions with similar size and legal traditions. 
 
9.  Output 2: Capacity of the investigators in IAAC, prosecutors in GPO, and judges in 
the judiciary enhanced. Based on the results of the diagnostic assessment, the output will 
provide capacity development for IAAC, GPO, and JGC in the areas most urgently requiring 
rectification. Given the limited TA budget, the capacity building activities will adopt the training-of-
trainers method. Participants will be selected based on criteria to be agreed between the law 
enforcement agencies and ADB. At the end of the training, it is expected that the participants will 
prepare handbooks that can then be disseminated widely. 
 
10.  Output 3: Changes to corruption-related reporting mechanisms, guidelines, laws, 
and regulations recommended. Based on the diagnostic assessment, ADB will recommend 
measures to fill the gaps found in the corruption-related reporting mechanisms, guidelines, laws, 
and regulations and to allow Mongolia to effectively strengthen its anticorruption regime. 
                                                
9  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $550,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff 
remuneration,  office  accommodation,  logistics  and  administrative  support,  organization  of 
conferences and workshops, printing of training materials, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
12.  ADB will implement the TA from December 2018 to 30 June 2021. IAAC will be the 
executing agency. The GPO and the JGC will be the implementing agencies. ADB's Mongolia 
Resident Mission will lead the TA and will take a one-ADB approach by working closely with other 
ADB departments, such as the (i) Office of the General Counsel, (ii) Office of Anticorruption and 
Integrity, and (iii) Department of Communications (regarding the conduct of workshops and 
training programs and the publication of knowledge products).10 IAAC will establish a working 
group that will consist of representatives (at least at the director level) of the executing and 
implementing agencies as well as the TA coordinator (a consultant recruited under the TA). The 
working group will be chaired by an IAAC representative with the TA coordinator as the secretary. 
ADB and the working group will meet each quarter, and more often if needed, to supervise the 
(i) TA's progress, (ii) annual and quarterly TA work plans, and (iii) self-assessment questionnaires 
and other major documents to be produced under the TA. ADB will administer the TA and be 
responsible for the recruitment and contracting of all consultants in close collaboration with the 
working group throughout the  recruitment  process. The consultants  will  be  responsible for 
organizing and delivering training to improve the capacity of government staff. At least three 
workshops (inception, midterm, and final) will be held in addition to the training. 
 
13.  TA support for workshops may include costs related to the venue, equipment rental, 
translations, printing and copying, meals, transport, lodging, logistics and administrative support, 
and other expenditures with prior agreement from ADB. In line with standard ADB procedures, 
the TA will not support the executing agency’s management fees or related costs such as staff 
salaries and allowances; other executing agency resources, such as office accommodation, will 
be provided as part of the counterpart contribution. 
 
14.  The executing agency will provide office space, servers, and other equipment required to 
run the activities. It will also provide access to utilities and telecommunications (including a 
broadband internet connection) for the consultants. It will supply data and documents as required 
under the TA. The executing agency will designate a TA focal point with strong English speaking 
and writing skills, and will facilitate all TA activities and links to local government representatives 
and providers to ensure effective implementation of TA activities. 
 
15.  The executing agency will establish a separate advance payment facility in United States 
dollars at a commercial bank acceptable to ADB in coordination with the Ministry of Finance and 
in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time). This will be used to pay for the workshop and training costs, survey costs, and 
report-publishing costs. 
 
                                                
10 The TA team will explore collaboration with the United Nations Development Programme, the World Bank, and other 
development partners.

4 
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table below.

17.  Consulting services. The TA will require 8 person-months of international and 32 person-
months of national consulting services. This includes recruitment of a firm, nongovernment 
organization, research institute, or think tank for the diagnostic assessment; international and 
national individual consultants for the legislation review; and an individual national consultant to 
coordinate the TA implementation. Where appropriate, and with concurrence of its Procurement, 
Portfolio and Financial Management Department, ADB will explore the use of output-based 
contracts  for  individual  consultants  to  ensure  administrative  efficiency  and  to  simplify  the 
disbursement process. The TA will engage resource persons to deliver the capacity development 
activities.  The  TA  will  also  cover  the  costs  of  interpretation  and  translations,  and  other 
miscellaneous costs. ADB will engage the consultants in line with the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.11 
 
18.  The consultants will be responsible for producing the TA outputs and deliverables in a 
timely and effective manner, and for organizing and carrying out all TA activities. They will report 
to the ADB project officer. ADB will evaluate the progress of the TA during review missions and 
workshops, based on the performance targets and indicators defined in the design and monitoring 
framework (Appendix 1). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Mongolia for Strengthening the Anticorruption Regime, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.  
                                                
11 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1. Diagnostic assessment of the reporting, investigation, prosecution, and adjudication of 
corruption cases prepared 
1.1 Agree with executing agency and all implementing agencies on terms of reference for diagnostic 
assessment by Q2 2019. 
1.2 Engage consulting firm to undertake diagnostic assessment by Q3 2019. 
1.3 Prepare draft report and organize workshop with executing and implementing agencies by 
Q4 2019. 
1.4 Translate final diagnostic assessment findings and hold dissemination workshop by Q1 2020. 
 
2.  Capacity of the investigators in IAAC, the prosecutors in the GPO, and judges in the 
judiciary enhanced 
2.1 Agree with executing and implementing agencies on training plan, including identification of 
individuals to be trained, by Q2 2020. 
2.2  Initiate training by Q3 2020. 
2.3  Complete training and prepare and translate training handbooks by Q1 2021 
 
3.  Changes to corruption-related reporting mechanisms, guidelines, laws, and regulations 
recommended 
3.1 Recruit consultants to prepare legal report and provide recommendations by Q4 2019. 
3.2  Prepare and translate report with recommendations on legal changes by Q4 2020. 
 
TA Management Activities 
Establish working group encompassing members of IAAC, GPO, the Judicial General Council, and the 
Ministry of Justice and Home Affairs in Q1 2019. 
Recruit TA coordinator by Q1 2019. 
Organize inception workshop with key project stakeholders by Q2 2019. 
Hold midterm workshop with key project stakeholders by Q1 2020. 
Hold final workshop with key project stakeholders by Q2 2021. 
Prepare inception (Q2 2019), midterm (Q1 2020), and completion (Q2 2021) reports. 
Inputs 
Asian Development Bank: $500,000 from Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6)

office accommodation, logistics and administrative support, organization of conferences and 
workshops, printing of training materials, and other in-kind contributions.
